newsitem.title: SPAIN: SOCCER-SPANISH LEAGUE FIXTURES THIS WEEKEND.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-SPANISH LEAGUE FIXTURES THIS WEEKEND.

text.p: Matches scheduled for this weekend in the Spanish first division (kick-off times GMT, league positions in parentheses):

Valladolid manager Vicente Cantatore is looking to clock up a record of home victories in a season against an Extremadura side that will be without injured Argentine striker Carlos Dure and striker Ivan Perez, who signed on Thursday for Real Madrid.

Real will be looking to seal the Spanish championship with their first league win at the Camp Nou since the 1983-84 season. For Barcelona the clash is vital in their aspirations to take Spain's second place in the European Cup.

Bottom club Logrones are 11 points away from safety, and desperately need a result against high-flying Betis, who will rest winger Emmanuel Amunike ahead of next week's derby game with Sevilla but welcome back suspended striker Alfonso Perez.
Real Sociedad hope to bring back midfielder Javi De Pedro from injury for a meeting between two teams that are drifting in mid-table but still have outside hopes of a UEFA Cup place.
Sporting may bring in reserve team striker Ruben Blaya in their bid to escape relegation. They will be looking to end their poor run against a Celta side who are particularly weak away from home.

Flavio Maestri reappears after suspension for Hercules, who will be accompanied by several thousand fans to the game with Sevilla, who are immersed in a boardroom crisis which produced a demonstration of 15,000 supporters on Thursday.
Compostela have gone nine games undefeated at home, and have never lost in Santiago to Rayo, whose own strength is in away games.
Abel Xabier and Paulo Bento are out injured for Oviedo against a Tenerife outfit still in with a chance of winning one of Spain's four UEFA Cup places.
Zaragoza will bring in former Real Madrid defender Miquel Soler for an uphill battle against an Espanyol side who have taken 19 of the last 21 points from home games.

Atletico have won their last three home games with Athletic and hope to continue their recent recovery with a victory that would virtually guarantee a UEFA Cup place for next season. The visitors have international striker Julen Guerrero suspended.
Deportivo have won twice in their last three visits to Valencia and will look for another result on a day in which Barcelona face a stiff test in the battle for Spain's second European Cup place.
